questions.question: A mother brought a healthy-looking, 3-month-old infant for routine immunization. As youwere giving the shot, you noticed some noisy breathing in the baby, which became worse oncehe started crying. However, it decreased, as you held him in a prone position. There were noclear signs of distress. According to his mother, he had been feeding well at home and has nothad any episodes of apnea or cyanosis. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A senior casualty nurse informs you that a 5-year-old girl with severe respiratory distressmight require intubation. You just finished stabilising and placing an ET tube in Mohan, a57-year-old man with head trauma and a GCS of 7. Which of the following is not a feature ofchild's airway?

options.A: The larynx being located higher in the neck at the level of C3-C4
options.B: The narrowest part being the subglottic region

questions.explanation: The pediatric airway is funnel shaped. In comparison, the adult airway is cylindrical.433In newborns, the larynx is situated at the level of C3-C4, where it facilitates simultaneousrespiration and swallowing during feeding.

questions.question: During a night shift, you get a call from the ER to come and see a toddler, who presented withcomplaints of fever, drooling, and a muffled voice since evening. On examination, the childhas a stridor and you pick up a "thumb sign" on the lateral x-ray of his neck. What is the mostlikely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Thumb sign on lateral x-ray of neck is pathognomonic for acute epiglottitis (AE). It is seen due toepiglottic enlargement.AE is an inflammation of the epiglottis. The arytenoids, false cords, and posterior tongue may alsobe involved.In children, Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause. This has decreaseddramatically since the widespread availability of immunization (pentavalent). Streptococcuspyogenes, S. pneumoniae, and S. aureus have also been implicated. Non-infectious causes can beforeign body ingestion and trauma from thermal or caustic agents.It has a progressive and potentially fulminating course, characterised by high fever, sore throat,dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.AE is a clinical diagnosis and a true emergency, X-ray soft tissue neck is not necessary to confirmit. It may be used to rule out differentials such as laryngotracheobronchitis, foreign bodyobstruction, retropharyngeal abscess or congenital anomalies. The time taken for X-rays should beavoided in a critically ill child due to the risk of sudden complete airway obstruction.The definitive diagnosis of AE is made during direct laryngoscopy. However, since manipulationcan induce a laryngospasm, it is generally avoided.The image below shows thumb sign:

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common etiological agent associated with epiglottitis inchildren, overall in the world?
questions.explanation: 434The most common etiological agent, overall in the world, of acute epiglottitis in the pediatric agegroup, now is Streptococcus.In the past, Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) used to be the most commonly identified causeof acute epiglottitis. But, since the widespread use of the H. influenzae type b vaccine, invasivedisease caused by H. influenzae type b in pediatric patients has been reduced by 99%.Therefore, other organisms, such as Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS), Streptococcus penumoniae,non-typeable H. influenzae, and Staphylococcus aureus, have become the common causes of acuteepiglottitis in pediatric age group, overall in the world.Lateral X-ray of the neck shows the thumb sign in acute epiglottitis.

questions.question: A 5 year old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough forpast 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition?R
questions.explanation: Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenzavirus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinicalfeatures include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.Management:• Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillaryhydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.• Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the gradesof croup..Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

questions.question: 4232-year-old Neha has been having fever since yesterday and is refusing food. Parents becamealarmed when she developed an abnormal barking cough today morning and have broughther to the casualty. On examination, the child looked exhausted and had visible chestretractions and stridor. The temperature was 39.6 degrees and SpO2 was 93% on room air.Chest X-ray reveals a 'steeple' sign. What is the treatment of choice in this child?

options.C: Send a throat swab and start IV antibiotics

questions.explanation: Fever, barking cough, inspiratory stridor and a steeple sign on chest radiograph are suggestive ofacute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The treatment of choice in this child is nebulization withracemic epinephrine.Epinephrine acts rapidly and provides immediate relief. It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in theupper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure. This increases fluid resorptionand reduces airway edema.Westley Croup Severity Score:Overall score and severity• o to 2- mild• 3 to 7- moderate• 8 to 11- severe435• 12 to 17- impending respiratory failureTreatment of moderate to severe croup:• Racemic epinephrine nebulization• Dexamethasone is indicated in all grades of croup and is given by the least invasive route.(Oral>IM>IV)•• Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)• Antibiotics are not indicated in croupFeatureStridor1234NoneWith agitatioAt restnAir EntryNormalDecreasedMarkedly decreasedRetractionsNoneMildModerateSeverCyanosisLevel of ConsciousnesSNoneNormal,including sleePLO5With agitatioAt RestnDisoriented

questions.question: A child in your unit is admitted with acute bronchiolitis. Which of the following is the mostcommon etiological agent responsible for this condition during infancy?
questions.explanation: Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease in children younger than 2 years. Respiratorysyncytial virus (RSV) is the most likely etiological agent and is responsible for more than 50% ofcases.Acute bronchiolitis refers to airway inflammation and obstruction of the lower respiratory tract.Clinical features of bronchiolitis include fever, cough, fine inspiratory crackles, expiratorywheezes, and breathing difficulty. Cyanosis may be seen in severe cases.Radiographs may be normal in some patients. In the majority of them, there will be interstitialinfiltrates, hyper-expansion of the chest, and peribronchial thickening.Management is mainly conservative. Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen.Rarely, a child might develop respiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasiveventilation.

questions.question: 10-month-old Ishaan was presented to the OPD with a 3-day history of lower respiratory tractsymptoms and an expiratory wheeze. Chest X-ray showed mild peribronchial thickening.Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition described?

options.A: The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smoked during pregnancy.
options.B: It is more common in children who have not been breastfed.
options.C: The mainstay of treatment is antibiotics.
options.D: There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bronchiolitis. The treatment is mainly supportive.Hypoxemic children should receive cool, humidified oxygen. Rarely, a child might developrespiratory failure and require hospitalization and invasive ventilation.436It is more common in boys, in those who have not been breastfed, and in those who live incrowded conditions. The risk is higher for infants with young mothers or mothers who smokedduring pregnancy.Acute bronchiolitis is predominantly a viral disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)and antibiotics are not indicated.There is a higher incidence of wheezing and asthma in children with a history of bronchiolitis.

questions.question: The pediatric intensivist is contemplating whether to start aerosolized ribavirin in a youngboy with a severe respiratory infection. There would be a clear indication to start the drug if

options.B: The child has not received any immunization
options.C: There is a history of severe atopy
options.D: There is a history of recurrent infection

questions.explanation: Ribavirin is the only specific antiviral therapy available for the treatment of severe bronchiolitiscaused by RSV infections. It is reserved as a last-line agent for life-threatening bronchiolitis inpatients who are immunocompromised or who have hemodynamically significantcardiopulmonary disease. In otherwise healthy children, the management of acute RSVbronchiolitis is typically supportive.Ribavirin is a prodrug, which when metabolized resembles purine RNA nucleotides. In this form,it interferes with RNA metabolism required for viral replication.MNEMONIC: (for indications of ribavirin)• C-RIBAvirin:••Hepatitis C• RSV• Influenza B• Arenaviruses (Lassa, Bolivian, etc.)Note Ribavirin is also used in the treatment of hepatitis C and some viral hemorrhagic fevers.-

questions.question: 3-year-old Sravya was referred with a one-week history of being unable to look upwards,constant neck flexion, and deviation to the right side. Parents also complained of feedingdifficulty. On examination, the child was noted to have poor oral hygiene and the neck wastender on palpation. The X-ray is given below. Which of the following statements are falseabout the given condition?

options.A: It occurs mostly in children younger than 3-4 years
options.B: It is more common in boys
options.C: Examination shows unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall
options.D: Trauma to the posterior pharynx is the most common cause

questions.explanation: The history of progressive torticollis, neck pain and dysphagia in a young child along with a neckX-ray demonstrating a prevertebral soft-tissue swelling are all indicative of a retropharyngealabscess. In young children, an antecedent upper respiratory tract infection is the most commoncause of an RP abscess and not trauma.It involves the suppuration of lymph nodes present in the RP space and is more common inchildren younger than 3-4 years since these lymph node chains involute after 5 years of age. Boysare affected more often than girls. In older children and adults, the cause is usually trauma to theposterior pharynx, which leads to inoculation of the retropharyngeal space.Risk factors include poor oral hygiene, diabetes, an immunocompromised state, and lowsocioeconomic status.Clinical manifestations are nonspecific and include fever, decreased oral intake, and drooling.Neck stiffness and torticollis may also be present. As the abscess grows in size, it can also lead toupper airway obstruction and asphyxiation. The physical examination can reveal unilateral437bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall.Although lateral radiograph is used for initial imaging, CT of the neck with intravenous contrast isthe best imaging study to evaluate patients with a retropharyngeal abscess. Treatment rangesfrom prolonged courses of intravenous antibiotics to surgical incision and drainage.

questions.question: The most common cause of bacterial pneumonia in children 3 weeks to 4 years of age is
questions.explanation: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is the most common bacterial pathogen in children 3weeks to 4 years of age.Aetiology of infectious pneumonia grouped by age of the patient:Age group< 3 weeks3 weeks - 4 yearS> 4 yearsFrequent pathogens (in orderof frequency)Group B Streptococcus, E.coli, gram-negative bacilli, S. pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae (type b)RSV, other respiratory viruses (rhinovirus, influenza, parainfluenza and adenovirus),S.pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae (type b), MycoplasmapneumoniaeMycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydophila pneumoniae, S.pneumoniae, Hemophilus influenzae (type b)

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presented with a 4-day history of high-grade fever and a productive coughwith yellow sputum. Chest x-ray showed a consolidation in the right middle zone. Accordingto WHO guidelines, which of the following is not an indication for hospital admission?
questions.explanation: As per the revised 2014 WHO guidelines, it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home.However, a child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred forinpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having“severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission).Danger signs:• Not able to drink•Persistent vomiting• ConvulsionsLethargic or unconscious•Stridor in a calm child438• Severe malnutritionCough and cold:Home care adviceno pneumoniaChild age2-59 monthswith coughand/ordifficultbreathingFast breathing and/Oral amoxicillin andhome care adviceor chest indrawing:pneumoniaGeneral dangersigns: severepneumonia or verysevere diseaseFirst doseantibiotic andreferral to facilityfor injectableantibiotic/supportive therapy

questions.question: A 5th standard girl is brought to the OPD with a high fever and cough with expectoration for3 days. Her chest X-ray shows multiple pneumatoceles. Which of the following is the mostcommon etiological agent implicated in this presentation?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is oftenunilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas ofcavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times,bronchopulmonary fistulas.The following CT image shows cavitating pneumonia by S. aureus:

questions.question: A one-and-half-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever,cough, and cold. On examination, respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chestretractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.B: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
options.C: Oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home
options.D: No need of treatment only home remedies

questions.explanation: 439The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute respiratory illness. According to the IMNCIguidelines 2020, this child can be classified as having 'Pneumonia'. The treatment is oralamoxicillin, vitamin A and home care advice.SIGNSCLASSIFY ASAny general danger signVERY SEVEREPNEUMONIAAny general danger signOROxygen saturation < 90%•Stridor in calm childCentral CyanosisAVPU=V, P or UChest indrawing in calm childORFast breathing ANDNo signs of severepneumoniaSEVERE PNEUMONIAPNEUMONIANo signs of pneumonia orNO PNEUMONIA:very severe disease.COUGH OR COLD"AVPU-Alert, responsive to Voice, responsive to Pain, UnresponsiveTREATMENTGive diazepam if convulsing nowQuickly complete the assessmentGive any pre-referral treatment immediatelyTreat to prevent low blood sugarKeep the child warmRefer URGENTLY• Screen for possible TB and HIVIf saturation <90%, start oxygen therapy and refer or admitGive the first dose of Benzyl Penicillin & Gentamicin•Treat for and to prevent low blood sugarKeep the child warmTreat wheeze if present, admit or refer urgently to hospitalScreen for possible TB and HIVGive Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablet and Vitamin AIf wheezing, treat and follow-up in 2 daysSoothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy• Screen for possible TB and HIVReview in 2 days, if not possible, admit OR refer children withchest indrawingAdvise mother when to return immediatelyIf wheezing, treat and follow-up in 2 daysSoothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedyFollow-up in 5 days if not improvingScreen for possible TB and HIVAdvise mother when to return immediatelyFast breathing is defined as given in the table below:Age of childFast breathingRR<2 months60 breaths/min2-12 months50 breaths/min1-5 years40 breaths/min

questions.question: 426An adolescent boy with a family history of asthma presented with intermittent wheeze andcough for 2 months. The onset of wheeze is triggered during exercise and while playing atschool. Which of the following is preferred as regular therapy for the prevention of hissymptoms?
questions.explanation: Inhaled corticosteroids are recommended as regular therapy for the prevention of his symptomsof exercise-induced asthma.According to GINA 2021 guidelines, exercise-induced bronchoconstriction can be prevented withdaily treatment (regular therapy) with inhaled corticosteroids. SABA, LABA, or chromones may beused prior to exercise, along with warm-up before exercise.Those who have mild exercise-induced asthma can use their regular inhaled corticosteroid beforeexercise and need not take SABA pre-exercise.

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has ahistory of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetictesting in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to bedecreased in this patient?
questions.explanation: 440The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is mostlikely to be decreased.Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffianduct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective spermtransport resulting in obstructive azoospermia.The sexual function is generally unimpaired.Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (≥60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTRprotein leading to defective chloride transport.Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweatresulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreaticinsufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

questions.question: Which of the following has similar inheritance pattern as cystic fibrosis?

options.A: Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome
options.B: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4

questions.explanation: Cystic fibrosis (CF), is an autosomal-recessive disorder. Accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomeis seen in Pompe's disease which is another autosomal-recessive disorder.Option B: Trinucleotide repeat expansion of CAG on chromosome 4 is seen in Huntington'sdisease, which is autosomal dominant.Options C and D: Adult-onset polycystic kidney disease and retinoblastoma (RB gene mutation)are autosomal-dominant diseases.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about cystic fibrosis is not true?

options.B: Abnormality in CFTR gene leads to defective calcium transport.
options.C: Mutation in cystic fibrosis transport regulator is seen.427
options.D: Males have infertility in adult life

questions.explanation: In cystic fibrosis, abnormalities in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator(CFTR) gene lead to defective chloride channels and not calcium channels.Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal-recessive disorder of children and adults. Dysfunction of theCFTR, the primary defect, leads to a wide and variable array of presenting manifestations andcomplications.The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.More than 95% of males are azoospermic because of failure of development of Wolffian ductstructures, but the sexual function is generally unimpaired.

questions.question: The most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis among the pediatric agegroup is
questions.explanation: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing pneumonia in cystic fibrosis amongthe given options.The most common organisms causing pneumonia in CF patients:441• The pediatric age group- S. aureus• The adult population- P. aeruginosa (mucoid)Pseudomonas aeruginosa-mucoid may also cause pneumonia in pediatric CF patients.In cystic fibrosis, P. aeruginosa shows a special feature of developing a mucoid capsule. Thiscomplex polysaccharide generates a biofilm that provides a hypoxic environment and therebyprotects Pseudomonas against antimicrobial agents.Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia is associated with higher mortality, but it is not the mostcommon. These patients are found to have severe pulmonary hypertension, possibly due topulmonary inflammatory vascular response.

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy was evaluated for cystic fibrosis. Sweat chloride shows value of 38 and 44mEq/L (normal<40). Which is the next best test to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.explanation: DNA analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in patients with equivocal (onenormal and one abnormal value) or frankly normal sweat chloride values.The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:• Presence of•⚫ Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, orgenitourinary) or•Positive newborn screening or• A sibling with cystic fibrosis• Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by• Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or••Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or•An abnormal measurement of nasal potential differenceOptions A and B: 72-hour fecal fat and chest CT are not used in the diagnosis of CF.Option D: This testing is primarily used in research applications and has never undergoneextensive validation as a clinical tool.

questions.question: A couple planning for pregnancy visits you for genetic counseling. They are both known to beheterozygous carriers of CFTR mutations. Which of the following is the most likelycomplication in an affected child at birth?
questions.explanation: CFTR mutations are associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). Meconium ileus is a commoncomplication associated with CF patients at birth.Meconium found in the intestine of a neonate consists of succus entericus (bile salts, bile acids,and debris from the intestinal mucosa) and is normally evacuated within 6 hours of birth (orearlier).Meconium ileus occurs in the first 24-48 hours of life when meconium becomes inspissated andobstructs the distal ileum causing abdominal distension and emesis. Abdominal radiographs show442dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels and, frequently, a collection of granular, “ground-glass”material in the lower central abdomen.Meconium ileus may also be seen with pancreatic atresia or pancreatic duct stenosis.Radiological image shows contrast enema in a newborn infant with abdominal distention andfailure to pass meconium. Several air-fluid levels in the small bowel are visible on the uprightlateral view.

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy, diagnosed with cystic fibrosis shortly after birth has been having around 2-3exacerbations per year, requiring hospital admissions. Infection by which of the following428organisms has increased mortality in such patients?
questions.explanation: Cystic fibrosis patients with Burkholderia cepacia pneumonia are found to have severe pulmonaryhypertension, possibly due to pulmonary inflammatory vascular response, and have highermortality.Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (mucoid) are the most common pathogenscausing pneumonia in CF patients. However, they have lower mortality compared to B. cepacia.

questions.question: A 3-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent pneumonia and chronic diarrhea. Hismother states that he has 6-8 foul-smelling stools per day. Physical examination reveals alow-grade fever and scattered rhonchi over both lung fields. Sweat chloride testing is elevatedon 2 separate occasions. Which of the following drugs is used as a treatment option for thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). Ivacaftor is used in the treatment ofcystic fibrosis.Ivacaftor is a potentiator of the chloride channel and overcomes its defect. It activates theCFTR-G551D mutant protein.Remember: IvaCaFTOR (CFTR mutation in CF)

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl presented with cough and difficulty breathing following accidental inhalationof a peanut. On examination, there was localised wheezing and decreased breath sounds onthe right side. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation: 443In a child with a suspected foreign body in the lung, the next best step would be to do a rigidbronchoscopy as it is both diagnostic and therapeutic.The rigid bronchoscope has a ventilation mechanism and a suction port making it easy forvisualization and handling of the foreign body. However, it is pertinent to note that the initialinvestigation is usually a chest X-ray.

questions.question: All the following are true about Macleod syndrome except that

options.A: It is also called Swyer-James syndrome.
options.B: It is not a true emphysema.
options.C: It is mostly linked to adenovirus.429
options.D: Affected lung is larger in size compared to unaffected lung.

questions.explanation: Macleod syndrome refers to the inability of the lungs to grow after a severe obstructivebronchiolitis. Children with this condition often have chronic cough, recurrent pneumonia, andwheezing. On CT scan, the affected lung shows small size and decreased vascularity,hyperexpansion, and hyperlucency (false emphysema).It is also called Swyer-James syndrome. It is mostly linked to adenovirus. Patients respond wellto bronchodilators.

questions.question: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. Aftera detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of thefollowing are components of the Kartagener triad except
questions.explanation: Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.Kartagener's syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of:• Situs inversus•Chronic sinusitis•⚫ BronchiectasisPrimary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorderaffecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. Thiscauses the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, thismanifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest andabdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotilespermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.question: All the following are components of Young's syndrome except:
questions.explanation: Asthma is not usually seen in Young's syndrome.Young's syndrome is characterized by:• Bronchiectasis• Sinusitis444• Obstructive azoospermiaIn contrast, Kartagener's syndrome is characterized by• Bronchiectasis• Sinusitis• Situs inversus

questions.question: A term male neonate develops respiratory distress at birth, unresponsive to surfactant.Echocardiography is normal and chest X-ray shows a ground-glass appearance. Parents saythat their first child died at 10 days of birth due to similar complaints. What is the most likelydiagnosis?
questions.explanation: The history and chest X-ray findings are suggestive of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP).PAP is a rare, diffuse lung disease that is characterized by alveolar and interstitial accumulation ofa periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain-positive phospholipoprotein (derived from surfactant).Infants and children with PAP present with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, weight loss, chest pain, orhemoptysis. Boys are affected 3 times as often as girls.Chest X-ray shows ground-glass opacity and HRCT shows crazy-paving pattern (as shown below).DAILYROUNDSTreatment options include total lung lavage, inhaled or subcutaneous granulocyte-macrophagecolony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).

questions.question: 430A 3-month old previously healthy baby was brought to the casualty when the parents foundthat the baby was not breathing while asleep. Following resuscitative measures, the baby wasstill apnoeic, pulseless and asystolic. Which of the following is not a risk factor for suddeninfant death syndrome?

options.B: Infants born to women aged >35 years
options.C: Infants of mother who smoked during pregnancy

questions.explanation: Higher maternal age is not a risk factor for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).Risk factors for SIDS include• Low socioeconomic status• 3-4 months of age have the highest incidence445•Higher birth order irrespective of maternal age and low birth weight•Cigarette smoking, alcohol, and drug abuse during pregnancy•Sleeping prone, even side sleeping increases the risk

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant was admitted because of increasing stridor since birth, cough,pulmonary infections, and episodes of acute respiratory distress. On detailed evaluation usingbronchoscopy and MRI imaging, a bronchial cyst was found to be the cause. The following arefeatures of the lesion except that

options.B: It is usually confined to 1 lobe.
options.D: It is never associated with malignancy.

questions.explanation: Bronchial cysts are associated with malignancy (pleuropulmonary blastoma).Bronchial cysts are congenital malformations of the bronchial tree. It mainly presents asa mediastinal mass that may enlarge and cause local compression.It is usually confined to a single lobe and is mostly multiloculated.

questions.question: In a child with yellow nail syndrome, you would expect to find all the following clinicalfeatures except
questions.explanation: Yellow nail syndrome is not associated with clubbing.Yellow nail syndrome is characterized by respiratory manifestation (pleural effusion,bronchiectasis), lymphedema, and discoloured nails.Yellow nail syndrome almost always occurs after 50 years of age, but a juvenile or familial formhas also been observed.

questions.question: What is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a 2-year-old child?
questions.explanation: The most common mediastinal masses in young children are neurogenic tumours (50%-60%). Inmost cases (< 4 years of age), they are invariably malignant (neuroblastomas).Anterior mediastinal masses:Thymoma - most common• Malignant lymphoma (Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's)• Teratoma• Thyroid (retro- or sub-sternal extension).Thymic cystAngiomaMiddle mediastinal masses:• Foregut duplication cyst (bronchogenic, enteric, and neurenteric) - most common•⚫ Lymphadenopathy.• Vascular malformationsPosterior mediastinal masses:446• Neurogenic tumour most common overall•-Foregut duplication cyst• Vascular malformations•Extramedullary hematopoiesis447
